docs.snippet: When Ed Feldman, the producer of 15 movies from ''Save the Tiger'' to his current co-production ''The Golden Child'' starring Eddie Murphy, watched a television rerun of ''Mission: Impossible'' several months ago, he decided the television adventu...
docs.lead_paragraph: When Ed Feldman, the producer of 15 movies from ''Save the Tiger'' to his current co-production ''The Golden Child'' starring Eddie Murphy, watched a television rerun of ''Mission: Impossible'' several months ago, he decided the television adventure series, which ran from 1966 to 1973, ''could make a fun movie.'' So the series about a team of secret agents whose instructions self-destructed each week will be turned into a movie at Paramount. Peter Graves, who headed the television team after the show's first season, will co-star with three unknowns, and Mr. Feldman hopes the team members Greg Morris, Peter Lupus, Martin Landau and Barbara Bain will make cameo appearances. Paramount, which has had major success with three ''Star Trek'' movies, is also making a movie version of ''The Untouchables'' directed by Brian De Palma. At the moment, Mr. Feldman is the happy producer of ''Witness,'' which has been nominated for eight Academy Awards. Released last February, ''Witness'' defied the odds. ''Pictures released early in the year are almost never remembered,'' he said. ''I thought 'Mask' would be a major contender and Cher had a lock for best actress. I thought 'Purple Rose of Cairo' would be one of the five nominated best pictures. And 'The Breakfast Club' got exceptional reviews. 'Witness' couldn't have made it except that it ran six or eight months, long enough to keep it in the public's mind.''

byline.original: By Aljean Harmetz, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: An executive for a leading newspaper in the United States opposed to President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines was killed at his suburban Los Angeles home today in what some Marcos opponents say was a political assassination.   The news exe...
docs.lead_paragraph: An executive for a leading newspaper in the United States opposed to President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines was killed at his suburban Los Angeles home today in what some Marcos opponents say was a political assassination. The news executive, Oscar Salvatierra, was shot dead in Glendale this morning, two days after colleagues on The Philippine News said he received an unsigned death threat. A few days ago, Mr. Salvatierra appeared on television in an interview with the NBC-TV affiliate here, and said that he had been threatened in the past for his criticism of Mr. Marcos.

headline.main: OFFICIAL OF PAPER AIDING AQUINO SHOT

byline.original: By JUDITH CUMMINGS, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: THE 18th-century English poet William Shenstone once wrote, ''I thank God that my name is susceptible to no pun.'' (Compulsive punsters will doubtless regard this as a challenge, but I think they will have their work cut out.) In whatever 18th-cen...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE 18th-century English poet William Shenstone once wrote, ''I thank God that my name is susceptible to no pun.'' (Compulsive punsters will doubtless regard this as a challenge, but I think they will have their work cut out.) In whatever 18th-century corner of heaven he occupies, Shenstone must currently be taking a little complacent satisfaction in the appearance down on earth of a small volume - a sequel to earlier collections by the same author - called ''John Train's Most Remarkable Names'' (published by Clarkson Potter). Remarkable names naturally tend to be all too susceptible to puns, and many of the men and women listed by Mr. Train can only be regarded as hapless victims. Osborne Outhouse (Boston); Lo Fat (retired seaman, New York City); Dr. Stark Staring (University of Utrecht, the Netherlands); Mary Louise Pantzaroff (Huron County, Ohio) - whatever peculiar joys there are for the bearers of such names must surely have been exhausted long ago. And can anyone called Cigar Stubbs or Memory Lane or Shanda Lear get through life without at least occasionally wishing that his or her whimsically-minded parents had been able to resist temptation?

headline.main: A ROSE BY ANY OTHER NAME COULD BE FUNNY

docs.snippet: In a period of generally cold relations between the United States and the Soviet Union, academic cooperation in archeology, a potentially controversial field, has been steadily expanding since 1979.   The contacts have involved only a handful of s...
docs.lead_paragraph: In a period of generally cold relations between the United States and the Soviet Union, academic cooperation in archeology, a potentially controversial field, has been steadily expanding since 1979. The contacts have involved only a handful of scholars, and there has been some reticence and political tiptoeing on both sides, according to Dr. C. C. Lamberg-Karlovsky, an archeologist at Harvard University who is one of the organizers of the exchanges. The Soviet scholars, for example, have refrained from discussing their recent archeological work in Afghanistan, where Soviet troops are helping Afghan Government forces fight rebels; in the past the Americans, slightly nervous about being criticized by other scholars at home, had avoided publicizing their Soviet work. Exciting and Puzzling Ties Yet the academic link is regarded by a variety of top American archeologists as important, exciting, anomalous and, at times, puzzling. They cite the following developments, among others: * Some of the most prestigious archeologists on both sides have visited fellow specialists. The Americans include not only Dr. Lamberg-Karlovsky, who is director of Harvard's influential Peabody Museum of Archeology and Ethnology and is a widely known expert on the early Middle Eastern civilizations, but also Dr. Robert McC. Adams, Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution and one of the world's leading authorities on ancient Mesopotamia.

headline.main: SEARCH FOR ANCIENT CLUES LINKS U.S. AND SOVIET EXPERTS IN WARY EXCHANGE

byline.original: By COLIN CAMPBELL, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: IN 1935, shortly after Bette Davis received her first Academy Award, for the movie ''Dangerous,'' the actress wheedled out of her husband, Harold O. Nelson, the closely guarded secret of his middle name. It turned out to be Oscar. ''To tease him, ...
docs.lead_paragraph: IN 1935, shortly after Bette Davis received her first Academy Award, for the movie ''Dangerous,'' the actress wheedled out of her husband, Harold O. Nelson, the closely guarded secret of his middle name. It turned out to be Oscar. ''To tease him, I began to call my statuette 'Oscar,' '' the actress reminisced 20 years later. ''Soon, 'Oscar' was adopted by the industry - and that's how the Academy Award statuettes got their nickname.'' Miss Davis's story is only one of several versions of how ''Oscar'' got its name, and only one of many stories to come out of her legendary career. That career is the focus of ''All About Bette,'' a seven-week retrospective of 37 of Miss Davis's films that begins today at the Regency Theater, Broadway and 67th Street.

headline.main: BETTE DAVIS IS THE STAR OF A 37-FILM RETROSPECTIVE

docs.snippet: HE Big Five faces fundamental changes after three decades as college basketball's biggest and best intracity rivalry.   For some, any change will lead to the Big Five's collapse.   ''My feeling is that any tampering with the City Series is one ste...
docs.lead_paragraph: HE Big Five faces fundamental changes after three decades as college basketball's biggest and best intracity rivalry. For some, any change will lead to the Big Five's collapse. ''My feeling is that any tampering with the City Series is one step beyond,'' said William Bradshaw, the La Salle athletic director. ''The modern era might destroy the Big Five.'' Others feel that the only hope of survival is to change with the times.

docs.snippet: With Congress considering stringent new measures to stem immigration, a Mexican Senator is warning that the measure would only worsen their nation's grave economic crisis.   At a conference today on immigration, the Mexican Senator, Maria del Carm...
docs.lead_paragraph: With Congress considering stringent new measures to stem immigration, a Mexican Senator is warning that the measure would only worsen their nation's grave economic crisis. At a conference today on immigration, the Mexican Senator, Maria del Carmen Marquez de Romero Aceves, called on the United States to offer cooperation and assistance rather than a cold shoulder to Mexico as a means of relieving the economic pressures at the root of illegal immigration. ''Mexico prefers to export goods rather than labor,'' said Senator Marquez, who represents the Mexican state of Baja California. ''But to find the solutions we need the cooperation of this country to create the necessary conditions to make our own country more attractive.'' She urged that the United States lift restrictions on imports from Mexico.

docs.snippet: SINCE Milton Avery's death in 1965, no aspect of his work has gone unexamined. The early years, the late work, ''important'' paintings, Avery in black and white, Avery in Mexico -these are just a few of the themes that shows have been built around...
docs.lead_paragraph: SINCE Milton Avery's death in 1965, no aspect of his work has gone unexamined. The early years, the late work, ''important'' paintings, Avery in black and white, Avery in Mexico -these are just a few of the themes that shows have been built around, both before and after the Whitney retrospective of 1982. It's not a matter of whether a year has gone by without an exhibition (it hasn't), but of how many shows there have been in any given year, country and worldwide. This may not be the saturation coverage visited on Picasso, but it's getting there; sometimes the art world milks its successes as frantically as the media its disasters. Never mind the numbness that must inevitably afflict even the most devoted Avery admirers, of which the reviewer is one: The question is whether so subtle and low-key an artist can survive such treatment unharmed. The answer, prompted by the latest display, at the Grace Borgenicht Gallery, 724 Fifth Avenue, at 56th Street, is ''just barely.''

headline.main: ART: PORTRAITS BY MILTON AVERY AT BORGENICHT
